awd_titl_txt: Improving Employability Skills of Advanced Manufacturing Technicians through Industry Mentoring and Experiential Learning Activities
awd_abstract_narration:
Manufacturing has recently emerged as a major industry in North Texas, a predominately rural region of the US.  Although the manufacturing industry has created many career opportunities for trained production technicians, it is difficult to find appropriately skilled workers in the region. This project builds on the results of a previous Advanced Technological Education project at Grayson College.  The previous project established an Associate of Applied Science degree and certificate programs in Advanced Manufacturing Technology. The current project will develop an industry mentoring program and a new employability skills curriculum, to help address the needs of regional manufacturers for skilled technicians. Currently, only 25% of high school students in the region live within traveling distance to the college’s dual enrollment program in advanced manufacturing.  Thus, to meet the needs of more high school students, the project will also develop an online option for advanced manufacturing technician education, with flexible lab hours for hands-on instruction.

The project objectives are to: 1) improve student employability skills through a formal industry mentor program; 2) develop a new employability skills curriculum based on experiential learning; 3) increase awareness of advanced manufacturing career opportunities among targeted audiences; and 4) provide access for high school students in rural areas to a dual enrollment program leading to a certificate or degree in advanced manufacturing technology. The project evaluation will assess the effectiveness of the industry mentor training program, the preparedness of students in terms of employability skills, the level of public awareness of the advanced manufacturing program, and the degree to which student access has increased. This project is funded by the Advanced Technological Education program that focuses on the education of technicians for the advanced-technology fields that drive the nation's economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Grayson College has successfully implemented the second stage of its “Boosting New Careers in Advanced Manufacturing Program,” and now has a growing Advanced Manufacturing Technology Certificate Program (AMP). The certificate program has graduated multiple cohorts of students despite staffing and COVID-related challenges and continues to grow as it strives to meet the continued growing need for workers skilled in advanced manufacturing in its region. 

Evaluation components assessed at this point in programming are:

✔  The extent to which the program effectively recruits, retains, and graduates program students from its dual credit and traditional student populations;

✔ The extent to which the website is accessed and used as intended;

✔ The extent to which stakeholders are satisfied with program components;

✔ Identification of most and least helpful ATE-replicated strategies for: engagement, retention, and graduation of students into an advanced manufacturing career;

✔ Identification of supports and barriers within community and classroom contexts that influence implementation plans, processes, and outcomes; and

✔ Sustainability of program components upon completion of grant time period. 

Report results will be organized by these components. To assess progress, program evaluator Dr. Megan Mullins, program evaluator, in partnership with Dr. Dava Washburn, Principal Investigator, conducted the following research activities:

✔ Analysis of Secondary Institutional Data: Enrollment and Persistence Data.

✔ Survey Research: Pre- and post-tests of currently enrolled students.

✔ Website Analytics: Assessment of promotional website access by Website visitors.

✔ Individual Interviews: In-person interviews with program mentors.

✔   Focus Groups:  Student focus groups with dual credit high school and traditional college students enrolled in the program.

Project Is Implemented As Intended

Feedback for this section is based on mentor interviews, institutional data, website analytics, and student pre-post test results.

Website Development

During Year 2, program leadership contracted with a local web developer to create an AMP website that includes promotional information about the program and testimonials from former traditional and dual credit students, faculty, and industry partners. The website was launched in September 2022. Between August 1st 2022 and August 1st 2023, website analytics demonstrate high use. Specifically:

● 960 views and 607 users of the Advanced Manufacturing Program website, with 1.58 views per user for an average engagement time of two minutes. This demonstrates a 40% increase in users than in last year’s numbers (tracking began in September 2022).

●  Views continue to peak in September and January as students enroll in new coursework. These analytics suggest that development of the AMP website has been successful in promoting the AMP and increasing public interest in the program.

Hybrid Curriculum Development

Institutional data shows that all AMP courses are being offered in hybrid (in-person and online) format. Additionally, an open lab schedule has been implemented that allows students the flexibility to complete the required number of lab hours each week. This alleviates pressures that dual credit students face in having to choose the program over extracurricular activities. 

Student Familiarity with Manufacturing & Machining Skills

Regarding implementation of the curriculum, Year 3 pre-test results demonstrate that, at the start of their education at Grayson, students’ knowledge of the skill sets needed to complete their certification varied. On average, pre-test responses indicate that students were at least “Somewhat Familiar” (3) with safety, teamwork, decision-making, and both interpersonal and math skills, though were less familiar with the remaining skill sets, most notably basic machinist, motor controls, and PLC. Those who responded to the post-test survey averaged the same or slightly less familiarity with most skill sets, with the exception of safety, teamwork, and basic motor controls which averaged slightly higher familiarity ratings. 

 


Last Modified: 12/01/2023
Modified by: Dava M Washburn
